title: A mouse model of Citrobacter rodentium oral infection and evaluation of innate and adaptive immune responses
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Oral infection of mice with Citrobacter rodentium
Timing: 21 days
One day pre-infection (day −1).
8–9 weeks old mice are chosen for infection.
Record the weight of mice.
Fast the mice for 16 h with water given ad libitum before infection.
At day 0.
Orally gavage the mice with 5 × 106 CFU of C. rodentium in 200 μL PBS using the gavage needle (8#) (as shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/323-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Oral inoculation with C. rodentium
(A) The gavage needle.
(B) The procedure of oral gavage.
Insert the needle parallel to the upper jaw until the throat. Verticalize the needle and insert along the esophagus without any obstruction, until almost the whole needle is inserted (as shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Inject 200 μL of bacteria gently with no liquid overflowed from the mouth.
Resume the diet.
At day 1 to day 21.
Record the weight of mice every day, analyze the weight change according to the weight at day −1. See Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Observe the stool consistency and recorded as the scoring criteria (0: normal, 1: loose stool, 2: shapeless loose stool, 3: diarrhea, 4: diarrhea with bleeding).
Collect feces into sterile microcentrifuge tubes every other day. Detect the CFU of C. rodentium in the feces as the protocol of “Determine the C. rodentium CFU in the feces".
Detect the ILC3s response at day 5 as the protocol of “Assessment of the ILC3s response".
Detect the adaptive T cell response at day 10 and the antibody response at day 21 as the protocol of “Assessment of the adaptive humoral immune response".

Critical: 1. The gavage needle is stainless steel in material, 45 mm in length, and straight. 2. To make sure that the feces could be collected, avoid frightening the mice by moving the cage or making noise before the collection. 3. It is better to fetch the feces directly by attaching the microcentrifuge tube against the anus. When infected at a high dose or around day 5–7 post infection, the feces may be difficult to collect because of the dysentery. Watery stools can be scraped into the tube and estimate the volume instead of the weight.
Determine the C. rodentium CFU in the feces
Timing: 1 h
Make normalized fecal homogenate.
Weight the feces using an analytical balance and transfer it to a sterile 5 mL tube.
Add 1 mL PBS buffer to every 50 mg feces.
Homogenize the samples thoroughly using a tissue grinder.
Count the CFU of C. rodentium in the feces.
Prepare a U-bottom 96-well plate, 2 multichannel pipettes, and PBS buffer.
Add 180 μL PBS to interlaced column of the 96 well plate.
Add 20 μL of the sample to the first column. Mix with pipettes and transfer 20 μL to the next column, and so on.
For each sample, dot 10 μL of each well by the multichannel pipette with interlaced tips on the MacConkey Agar plate (as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/323-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. CFU counting of C. rodentium in the feces
(A and B) The model for the dilution of fecal homogenate (A) and CFU of C. rodentium dot on the MacConkey Agar plate in 10-fold dilution gradient (B).
(C) Other bacteria colonies like E. coli showing on the plate (black arrow).
Incubate the plate in 37°C for 12–16 h.

Count CFU of the last two countable dots on the plate (as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B). See Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Calculate the concentration of C. rodentium in the feces according to the formula:
C (CFU/g) = CFU in the dot × 2 × 10(n+3), n= the order of the dot counted. Take the samples shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B, the CFU=5 × 2 × 10(4+3) = 1 × 108 CFU/g.
Critical: 1. In step 1, wash the tissue grinder with ethanol twice and water twice between samples. In step 2, the data will be reliable if the ratio of two adjacent dots is approximately 10. 2. Other bacteria colonies should be excluded (as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Assessment of the ILC3s response
Timing: 5 h
Isolation of the lamina propria lymphocytes (LPLs) from the colon (Guo et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
At day 5 post infection, euthanize the mice by cervical vertebra dislocation and isolate the colon. Remove the content in the gut thoroughly by scraping, sliver the colon, and cut the tissues into 0.5 cm pieces.
Wash the tissues with 20 mL PBS in a 50 mL centrifuge tube by vertexing to clean up the content remained and transfer the tissues to Wash Buffer I.
Wash the tissues with 15 mL Wash Buffer I in 37°C, shake at 200 rpm on a shaking table for 20 min, twice.
Wash the tissues with 15 mL Wash Buffer II in 37°C, shake at 200 rpm on a shaking table for 20 min.
Digest the tissues in 2.5 mL digestion buffer in a C-tube in 37°C, shake at 150 rpm on a shaking table for 30 min.
Homogenize the tissues with the gentleMACS Dissociator for 1 minute and add 10 mL 1640 buffer to stop the digestion.

Apply the samples to the 70 μm cell filter to make single cell suspension.
Centrifuge the samples in 4°C, 650 × g for 5 min, resuspend the cells with 1 mL DMEM buffer and mix with 1 mL 80% Percoll solution (to make 40% Percoll solution) in a 5 mL tube.
Carefully add 1 mL 80% Percoll solution at the bottom of the suspension. The clear separation of layers should be observed (as shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
Centrifuge the samples in 4°C, 950 × g with no brake for 20 min. The cell cloud between 40% Percoll and 80% Percoll is the LPLs (as shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/323-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Isolation of LPLs by Percoll
The LPLs isolation from the colon before (A) and after (B) the centrifugation with Percoll.
Carefully remove the top layer of epithelial cells and upper 40% Percoll, collect the LPLs with the micropipette into a 5 mL tube.
Wash the cells with 4 mL FACS buffer by centrifuging at 4°C 650 × g for 5 min, twice. Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cells with 1 mL FACS buffer.
Mix 10 μL 0.4% Trypan Blue with 10 μL cells mixture, and count the unstained cells (living cells) with the hemocytometer. See Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Critical: 1. Store the tissues in PBS on the ice until the Wash Buffer I. 2. If the gentleMACS Dissociator is not available, cutting the tissue until homogenized by scissors is an option. In that case, the cutting step should be done before the digestion. 3. The viability of LPLs should be over 90% for further analysis. The average number of LPLs is usually about 1 × 106–5 × 106 per colon.

For all wash steps that are not mentioned specifically in this section, cells should be centrifuged at 4°C 650 × g for 5 min.
Examine ILC3 in the LPLs.
For quantifying ILC3s:
Resuspend 2 × 106 LPLs with 50 μL Blocking buffer to block Fc receptor internalization.
For staining ILC3s, incubate the LPLs with Antibody Mixture 1 in 4°C for 30 min.
Wash the cells with FACS buffer.
Fix the cells with 100 μL fixation buffer at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 20 min.
Wash the cells with 200 μL permeabilization buffer at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 3 times.
Incubate the cells with Antibody Mixture 2 in room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 30 min.
For function of ILC3s:
Resuspend 2 × 106 LPLs with 200 μL 1640 medium with 10% FBS, 10 mM HEPES and 1 mM Penicillin-Streptomycin and incubate at 37°C with 5% CO2. Stimulate with PMA (20 ng/mL) and Ionomycin (750 ng/mL) for 2 h, and add BFA for another 2 h.
Wash the cells with FACS buffer and incubate the LPLs with Antibody Mixture 1 in 4°C for 30 min.
Wash the cells with FACS buffer.
Fix the cells with the IC fixation buffer at 4°C for at least 12 h.
Wash the cells with the permeabilization buffer at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 3 times.
Incubate the cells with Antibody Mixture 3 in room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 30 min.
Wash and then resuspend the cells with FACS buffer, and detect the ILCs by flow cytometry.
Firstly, define lymphocytes by gating CD45+ population and exclude dead cells by gating V780− cells. In the colon, ILCs can be gated as CD3−CD90+CD127+. In ILCs, RORγt+ cells are defined as ILC3s. See Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Assessment of the adaptive humoral immune response
Timing: 4.5 h

For all wash steps in this section, cells should be centrifuged at 4°C, 650 × g for 5 min.
Detection of GCB and TFH response in the mesentery lymph nodes (mLNs) (Melo-Gonzalez et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]). In mLNs, the germinal center is the place where B cells become mature in stimulation, which could be regulated by TFH cells. TFH and GCB can promote the production of high affinity antibodies to maintain intestinal homeostasis (Hepworth et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).
At day 10 post infection, euthanize the mice by cervical vertebra dislocation and isolate the mLNs (as shown in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
Grind the mLNs to make single cell suspension.
Resuspend 2 × 106 lymphocytes with Blocking buffer to block Fc receptor internalization.
To stain GCB, incubate the lymphocytes with Antibody Mixture 4 in 4°C for 30 min.
To stain TFH, incubate the lymphocytes with biotin-labeled CXCR5 antibody in 4°C for 30 min.
Wash the cells FACS buffer in 4°C for twice, and then incubate the cells with Antibody Mixture 5 in 4°C for 30 min.
Wash and then resuspend the cells with FACS buffer, and detect the lymphocytes by flow cytometry.
Analysis of C. rodentium-specific antibodies in the serum (Wang et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]).
At day 21 post infection, collect the peripheral blood from epicanthic intravenous by the MiniCollect Capillary Blood Collection (0.9–1.1 mm inner diameter, 100 mm length). Euthanize the mice by cervical vertebra dislocation.
Store the blood in 4°C for at least 12 h, and then centrifuge in 4°C, 2500 × g for 30 min.
Carefully collect the supernatant and then centrifuge in 4°C, 13000 × g for 5 min. Collet the serum and store in 4°C for immediately usage or −80°C for longer storage.

Resuspend 1 × 108 C. rodentium with 100 μL PBS buffer with proteinase inhibitor. Dissociate C. rodentium by ultrasonication on the ice for 3 times, 1 minute per time. Add 300 μL B-PER Complete Bacterial Protein Extraction Reagent.
Mix with gentle vortex for 30 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C). Centrifuge in 4°C, 16000 × g for 20 min to remove the cell debris.
Quantify total protein with the BCA protein assay.
Coat C. rodentium antigens at 5 μg/mL in 100 μL coating buffer on 96-well plates at 4°C for at least 16 h, and then wash the plate with PBST buffer.
Incubate the diluted serum on the plate and detect IgG using HRP-labeled antibodies (SouthernBiotech) following the instruction of the kit.
Develop the plate with ABTS substrate (SouthernBiotech). Detect OD at 405 nm with an ELISA reader (BioTek).
Critical: (1) To find out the mLNs, you can firstly find the cecum and search upstream along the mesenteries. The mLNs are always located in the central point of the mesenteries, umbraculiferously connecting the small intestine (as shown in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A). All the mLNs should be collected. (2) When washing the biotin-labeled antibody, wash thoroughly by FACS buffer to avoid unspecific staining.
